main event: On May 17, 1957, in Detroit, Michigan, an unidentified flying object was tracked by radar, appearing as a well-defined blip about the size of a 10 cent piece on the radar scope. The object was initially observed at a distance of approximately 70 nautical miles and a speed of approximately 1250 knots.
interesting points: The object's radar signature appeared as a well-defined blip and was initially observed at a considerable distance with high speed.
The object was tracked for approximately 30 seconds before fading from the scope, changing course, and decreasing in distance.
Experienced radar operators and a radar sergeant were witnesses to the object's initial sighting and tracking.
The conclusion of the report suggested the possibility of the object being a balloon or aircraft, while also stating that it was not definitively identified as such.
The Selfridge Air Force Base and the 28th AAA Group were notified of the sighting and tracking of the unidentified object.
witnesses: experienced radar operators and radar sergeant
